I prefer the statistical explanation which you touched on, for entropy.  Order and disorder are very ambiguous terms and one can be confused for the other.  But if you think of it like bouncy balls in a container, you realize they will spread out, and the likelyhood of them being in any particular configuration is small.  Basically things become distributed.  A balanced coin given enough flips, will be near 50%, a 6 sided die will eventually have 1/6th chance for each number to be rolled.  A coin has less entropy than a 6 sided die, because there's more states a 6 sided die can take.  A molecule of air moving in a 2d plane has 360 degrees of freedom, all equally likely, so it's easy to see how in a 3d world with so much interacting the amount of entropy is insanely big.  One person's ordered chess board might be another person's mess, people can define order as simply a state they find desirable so ti's entirely too loose a term to truly understand why when you put a drop of color into a water bowl, the water bowl becomes evenly distributed in color over time.  Yet, one person might say that the system started out disorderly (non uniform) and became orderly (uniform distribution of color)  when in fact, this is exactly what entropy is, in action.  The molecules distributed evenly.  Heat does the same, and it's all driven by the same statistics as that flipping coin.  When you have a lot of ways to equally do something, and enough time/iterations, the average is represented.  Anyway that is the method I use to think of it as the order/disorder example always confused me.

Think about it with a simple analogy. If you run a hundred miles, i.e. you do work, you lose energy.  But if you rest and eat, that is let the food do the work, you gain energy.  The energy here is basically heat.    In Physics, energy is the potential to do work. So if you do x amount of work on an object, the object can then do x amount of work as well. This potential to be able to do x amount of work is energy.  To explain it with a VERY CRUDE analogy, if I slapped you, I did work on you. And now, you have a motive to slap me back. This motive, crudely, is energy.  So in retaliation, if you slap me back, you did work. But since you slapped me, you've lost your motive to slap me more.  Similarly if the object did the x amount of work, it lost its potential to do the x amount of work, i.e. it lost energy.

U represents "internal energy", which is constant according the first law of thermodynamics. There are two main forms of energy, "kinetic energy" [KE], the energy of motion, and "potential energy", [PE], the energy of position.  The kinetic energy of a particle is 1/2 m v^2 [m = mass, v = velocity]. The potential energy of a particle depends on a particle's position in space, and may vary depending on where other particles are as well.

Hi Syes. The second law of thermodynamics relates time and entropy. In any physical process, the entropy of an isolated system must not decrease. The universe is an isolated system. Therefore, anything that happens in the universe must not decrease the entropy of the universe. Therefore, the entropy of the universe can only increase in time. This is sometimes referred to as the "arrow of time", the fact that the future and the past can be determined by their change in the entropy of the universe relative to the present.

Dennis Haupt OK, that's fine. First let me state, that this is fundamental, classical physics and can be found in any major textbook on physics, thermodynamics or physical chemistry, so it's nothing that I make up. The basis is that humans by observation found out, that reactions seem to have a preferred direction. E.g. a ball falls from a table to the floor, but it never spontaneously jumps from the floor onto a table all by itself, or hydrogen and oxygen spontaneuosly react to water, but water never spontaneously dissociated in large amounts in to hydrogen and oxygen, although all of these reactions are perfectly possible on a molecular level. So why is that ? The answer to this question is that when these reaction occur, the entropy of the closed system (the universe) increases. This understanding resulted in the formulation of the 2nd law of thermodynamics which is: The entropy of the universe always increases. This means, that reactions, that reduce the entropy do not happen spontaneously. You can "force" these reactions to happen (e.g. in the case of water via electrolysis), but this requires the use of energy, If you use energy a part of this energy dissipates into heat, which increases energy and overcompensates the entropy decrease of the reaction you enforce using energy. Meaning that the net entropy of the reaction is now positive (entropy increases) and now can occur. One can have different views of what entropy exactly is. In my opinion the best interpretation is the statistical interpretation by Boltzmann, but in the end it means all the same: entropy equals a higher degree of freedom and therefore less order. I'll give you an example: lets look at Fe (iron), once solid and once gaseous. If it's solid, the movement of a single Fe atom is blocked by all of it's neighbors, but of you just make the block of iron hot enough it first melts (the Fe atom is still interacts with it's neighbors, but less strongly (the structure is less ordered) and if you heat it more, the Fe becomes gaseous and finally a plasma. From crystalline (solid) over liquid to gaseous and finally plasma the interaction of a Fe atom with it's neighbors decreases, therefore it is less blocked in it's movement and the entropy increases. The heat is just required to overcome the bondings. Something that would otherwise happen by itself, although it would take possibly billions of years. That's more or less the direction the nature moves and will end in the "heat death of the universe". (you might want to look this term up) This becomes more obvious when looking at an examples: take a bucket and separate it into 2 halves with a sheet of glass. Into one half you fill 1l of cold water, into the other half you fill 1l of hot red water. Then you remove the glass plane separating the halves. What's happening ? Well, both sides could stay separated (like oil and water would do), but they don't. Wait a few minutes and you will have a homogeneous some pinkish, hand-warm water in the bucket. This is because by mixing the entropy increases as the mix is less ordered than the parts staying separated. Basis for all of this is in the end statistical of molecules, atoms and particles together with the fact that the number of ordered states is much much much less than the number of unordered states (e.g. you there is just 1 state in which the numbers from 1 to 10 are ordered by size, there are some combinations that show order (e.g. from 10 to 1 by orer, or first uneven then even etc) but the overall number of combinations is 10! (which is 3628800) and practically all or them are unordered. Don't forget on the molecular level we are not talking about 10 things, but already about 6,22*10^23 molecules in just a single mol), so in the end entropy is just a statistical effect, because ordered states are so much less likely than unordered, which is why the overall entropy in the universe (the degree of unorder) is continuously increasing. (It could theoretically also decreases, but this is so incredibly unlikely that it will certainly have never happened during the lifetime of the universe until now.

Dennis Haupt 1) You got something wrong here. There are 3628800 possible permutations of the numbers from 1 to 10, where each can just occur once. Every single one of these permutations is obviously equally likely. How likely is it that 1 to 10 ordered by increasing size will be the outcome ? Exactly 1 / 3628800. How likely  is it that 10 to 1 ordered by decreasing size will appear ? Also 1 / 3628800. Lets say there are not only these 2 but around 23 additional permutations where a human will be able to detect some sort of "pattern" (any kind of order) in the permutation of the 10 numbers. If so, we end up with 25 overall ordered states. This means the likelihood of ordered systems is (rule of thumb) 25 / 3628800. This means the likelihood of all others (=unordered)  is 3628775 / 3628800 or 1 - 25 / 3628800 which is in first approximation nearly 1. The more particles bigger the difference in likelihood between "ordered" and "unordered" states (with 2 particles, we are at 50% each). You can do the maths by yourself. Instead of the numbers 1 to 10, just take the numbers 1 to 10^80 (10^80 is roughly the assumed number of particles in the visible universe) and you'll see. So the more particles, the closer the likelihood of all particle particles winding up in an unordered instead of an ordered state. So with increasing number of particles the likelihood increases until it is practically 1 (that is 100% chance), without ever exactly reaching it. So the more particles, the higher the likelihood, that entropy. That's simple maths and the basis of the second law of thermodynamics. This game continuous until the entropy in the universe is maximized, so the universe is in equilibrium and nothing happens. No stars no life, no radioactivity, nothing. verything is has ended / is dead. That's the aformentioned heat death of the universe and bothered quite a lot of scientists in the midst of 1800s when all of this was first discovered/understood. 2) It's fine if you can imagine such things, but that's perfectly irrelevant.What's important in science is, what can be measured and observed, not what can be fantasized. Personal believes or fantasies are completely irrelevant. The only thing that counts is measurable data and the its interpretation, not wishful thinking. If you want that, that's religion, not science. Fact is that the universe behaves in a way that only actions take place spontaneously that lead to an overall increase of entropy in the universe. The reason for this is given by Boltzmann's statistical interpretation of entropy. So in the end by maths. Entropy increases because the likelihood that it increases is so much greater, than the likelihood that it does not. BTW, this is also the explanation for the infamous "arrow of time", so why time seems to irreversibly flow just into a single direction from the past into the future, although all events should be (and in principle are) reversible. It's simply because the likelihood of this flow is practically 1, while the likelihood of moving from an unordered to a more ordered state is practically 0.

Dennis Haupt S = (H -G)/T That's the Gibbs equation, where S is the entropy measured in J/K. If you transform it you get: (Vdp - dG)/dT = S, where the d is the differential or for simplicitie's sake the difference between before and after a reaction. So you measure changes in pressure, free enthalpy and temperature and can calculate the Entropie S. Alternatively you can calculate the changes in entropy on a theoretical basis from differences in number of particles and der degrees of freedom between educts and products. And finally there is the famous Boltzmann equation, where S = k ln R, where k is the Boltzmann constant and R the number of states. In our former 10 number example, this would have been 3628800 for the closed system. For more information I'd like to refer you to: Tipler, Physics for a short intro to Thermodynamics, Atkins, Physical Chemistry (where roughly all of what i mentioned i explained in detail in roughly 50% of the book), or Landau Llifshitz, Statistical Physics if you want to dive really deep in this.

+Frank Schneider After looking at the data from several years ago (since 2000), the average increase in global temperatures is about 0.6 degrees C. There has been an increasing trend since around 1970 and onwards. If you plot a linear line, you'll see a positive slope. Only by going back to 1880 and taking the average temperatures up until now will you not see much change. From the data, it looks like the earth is heating up faster than the ice can compensate. This means that both the ice is melting and the land surface is getting warmer. And since the temperatures on land are less stable than the oceans, we will feel the effects first while the ice slowly melts. The sources are below. Where do you get your data?  http://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/global-temperature/ https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cag/time-series/global/globe/land_ocean/ytd/12/1880-2016.csv http://climate.nasa.gov/news/2490/nasa-analysis-finds-august-2016-another-record-month/

fqn 3 First: I guess we both agree, that the Earth is in principle warming, so there is no general disagreement here, BUT the T increase since 2000 is significantly less, than what it should have been . The curve should not show a relatively linear (and therefore constant) but a continuously increasing growth in T. E.g. if you compare the T increase with the increasing global CO2- etc. emissions (e.g. here https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-data), you'll see the average T-increase is by far not as high as it should be. This of course doesn't mean that the causality is broken (or doesn't exist at all), but that there are effects responsible for this discrepancy. One is of course lag. It simply takes some time to show an effect on a global scale. If I increase/decrease the CO2 emission in China today, T in Mexico will not increase/decrease tomorrow or even next year. Another (and more important effect) is buffering. This means we'll see the real increase in average T only after the ice-buffers (and especially Arctica) have been fully eliminated. It's like heating an iced drink. T of the liquid will stay at 4°C as long is there is ice in it. Once the ice is gone, you'll see T rise, because before this, the increase in T (external energy) is used to facilitate the phase shift of the frozen water. That's simple physics.
